topic.title: [UPDATED TEXT] Two law changes that protect you from an evil sibling
A messenger that doesn't reveal user IP address
topic.body:
I was thinking of a decentralized messenger which every message is either broadcast to:
1. whole network
or
2. if it consumes lots of traffic, only region or group of peers the recipient of message declare located there. 

This way, IP address of two party of conversation is not revealed to each other
For reducing meta-data usability for surveillance, message's sender's username can be encrypted inside message
I live in a country that I know for activists hiding IP address is more important from other things and unfortunately, Tor and VPN doesn't provide enough assurance.
Messengers like Tox are great for communication by persons you trust, but not strangers.

topic.title: Decentralized Bootstrapping [updated review]
topic.body:
###  1- Using blockchain
Not mentioned in below article, but I think PoS blockchain can not fight split-view attack, but in PoW blockchain, the client can put a time limit on miners hashing answers to find out if it is connected to a powerful international-scale blockchain 
or 
If the number of victims are high, their participation in mining pool make attack expensive, because the pool server also should participate in the attack and send fake block headers to these pool miners, but still have to reward them for their useless calculations
but I'm not an expert
https://ietresearch.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1049/blc2.12001
###  2- Using Certificate transparency method
This method is not decentralized but to some degree detects split-view attacks 
Note: Chromium already implemented version 1 of it. But I think Version 2 is only effective which the browser request "consistency proof" (although not as effective as blockchain)
#### Space usage reduction in method 2:
I don't think ZeroNet trackers would need to keep old versions of IP list. Probably only root of Merkle tree of old data would be enough (but again I'm not expert)


.

1632250393_14nAB5NywyhuWp8J2HUy83gLwUFqd.body:
> [gitcenter](#comment_1557_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di)
Sorry, by international-scale network I meant international-scale blockchain (with strong (fast) hashing power e.g. Ethereum)

> Using Certificate transparency method. I would appreciate it if you elaborated on how it helps bootstrapping at all.
bootloader would have to keep an append-only log of peers info (to implement log transparency similar to google certificate transparency). But as I mentioned above for disk space usage optimization probably only keeping root of Merkle tree of old versions of log would be enough

But probably blockchain method is best and without problem. These methods  can stop bootloader to redirect some users to specific network of peers so it can reduce chance of "content split-world attack"

**content split-world attack:**
For example, China government make a deal with the trackers to route Chinese users to peers it controls and show them a version of ZeroTalk that is approved by government ~~(with help of ZeroTalk key owner of course. He would sign an internation version of Zerotalk and another version acceptable by other regions).~~
